<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17 is: Use of the string handling functions from <string.h> shall not result in accesses beyond the bounds of the objects referenced by their pointer parameters.
This rule strictly applies to the Standard Library functions in <string.h> such as memcpy, memmove, memset, memcmp, strcpy, strncpy, strcat, strncat, strlen, and strspn.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>

It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of MHD_set_connection_value_n_nocheck_:
```c
static enum MHD_Result
MHD_set_connection_value_n_nocheck_ (struct MHD_Connection *connection,
                                     enum MHD_ValueKind kind,
                                     const char *key,
                                     size_t key_size,
                                     const char *value,
                                     size_t value_size)
{
  struct MHD_HTTP_Req_Header *pos;

  pos = MHD_connection_alloc_memory_ (connection,
                                      sizeof (struct MHD_HTTP_Res_Header));
  if (NULL == pos)
    return MHD_NO;
  pos->header = key;
  pos->header_size = key_size;
  pos->value = value;
  pos->value_size = value_size;
  pos->kind = kind;
  pos->next = NULL;
  /* append 'pos' to the linked list of headers */
  if (NULL == connection->rq.headers_received_tail)
  {
    connection->rq.headers_received = pos;
    connection->rq.headers_received_tail = pos;
  }
  else
  {
    connection->rq.headers_received_tail->next = pos;
    connection->rq.headers_received_tail = pos;
  }
  return MHD_YES;
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.

explanation: This function contains no direct calls to <string.h> functions (memcpy/strcpy/etc.) within the shown code, but it records pointer/size pairs (key/value and their sizes) into a newly allocated header structure and uses an allocation call. The listed fragments should be investigated because they affect how string/buffer data and sizes are stored and how much memory is allocated (including a suspicious sizeof(...) choice). Other lines in the function — initial return-on-NULL, pos->kind/pos->next assignments, and the linked-list append logic (connection->rq.headers_received*, tail updates, and the final return) — do not perform string handling or buffer copying themselves and therefore do not directly relate to MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17 and need not be investigated for this specific rule.
